title: England star Sam Burgess calls time on glorious rugby league career
text:
England international Sam Burgess has announced his immediate retirement from rugby league after a sensational career.

South Sydney Rabbitohs said on Wednesday that their captain has been forced to quit the sport due to a chronic left shoulder injury.

The 30-year-old previously played for Bradford Bulls before appearing 182 times for the National Rugby League's Rabbitohs from 2010.

Sam Burgess has announced his retirement from rugby league due to a chronic shoulder injury

Burgess won the 2014 NRL Grand Final with the Rabbitohs despite having a broken cheek bone

Rabbitohs co-owner Russell Crowe was emotional when he hugged Burgess after that final

SAM BURGESS' CAREER CV Rugby League 2006-09 - Bradford Bulls 2010-14 - South Sydney 2016-2019 - South Sydney Won 24 England caps Honours NRL winner 2014 Clive Churchill Medal winner 2014 NRL Team of the Decade member 2019 Rugby Union 2014-15 - Bath Won 5 England caps

At the Redfern-based club he was joined by older brother Luke in 2011 and younger twin siblings George in 2012 and Thomas the following year.

Burgess was part of the Souths side that won the 2014 NRL Grand Final, suffering a fractured eye socket and cheek bone in the first tackle of the game but continued to play in the win over the Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs.

For his performance, he won the Clive Churchill medal as man of the match and remains the only non-Australian to claim the award.

Burgess said in a statement on Wednesday: 'This decision was one of the hardest decisions I've had to make in my life, however the decision was out of my hands essentially.

'I am no longer able to be myself day in, day out on the training field and consequently the playing field.'

In 2014 Burgess was given the Rugby League International Federation's International Player of the Year, and won South Sydney's players' player five times and its best and fairest on three occasions.

(L to R): Sam Burgess; Luke Burgess, Julie Burgess, George Burgess and Thomas Burgess pose with the NRL Grand Final trophy in 2014

He had a brief sojourn from the sport when he switched to rugby union from 2014 to 2015

Burgess was a controversial inclusion in Stuart Lancaster's 2015 England World Cup squad

His retirement comes just weeks after Burgess split from wife Phoebe for a second time

He also played 24 Tests for his country and had two appearances for Great Britain.

He had a brief sojourn from the sport when he switched to rugby union and represented Bath in 2014-15 as well as turning out for England during its home Rugby World Cup.

Burgess formed part of Stuart Lancaster's ill-fated 2015 England World Cup squad, who became the first host nation not to make it out of the pool stages, but his performances were heavily scrutinised.

In his retirement statement he added: 'I'd like to encourage everyone to smile as they read this.

'Let's all remember what we have done together as a club over the past decade rather than what's not to be in the coming years.

His decision to end his rugby career comes just weeks after Burgess split from wife Phoebe for a second time.
description: South Sydney Rabbitohs said on Wednesday that their captain Sam Burgess has been forced to quit the sport due to a chronic left shoulder injury, ending one of rugby league's greatest careers.
